posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
Hello! If you regularly beta test the app, you‚Äôve probably noticed that there can be a large delay from when we announce a beta to when it‚Äôs actually available in the Play Store. This is because Google can take a very long time to review our app. Sometimes hours, sometimes days!

In the past, we used Firebase App Distribution to get releases out to testers more quickly. However, for various reasons, we had to drop support.

Thankfully, we‚Äôve decided on a new replacement! It‚Äôs called Obtainium, and it‚Äôs a pretty clever app. Rather than host APK‚Äôs directly, users simply tell Obtainium to watch a specific Github repo or URL, and it‚Äôll tell you when there‚Äôs a new version available for you to download. Quite elegant!

Here‚Äôs some more detailed instructions.

  1. Download and install Obtainium from the official website: Link
  2. Click on the ‚ÄúAdd App‚Äù button in the bottom bar.
    signal-2024-12-05-0933311024√ó2219 54.2 KB
  3. For the location, enter in our GitHub repo:
    https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android. For production releases, you can leave all the settings at default. But if you want the latest beta versions (which I‚Äôm guessing you do, if you‚Äôre reading this!), then enable the ‚ÄúInclude prereleases‚Äù toggle.
    image1080√ó2340 140 KB
  4. Click the ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button, and you‚Äôre good to go!

You should now be told whenever there‚Äôs a new release!

Alternatively, you can always choose to manually go to our releases page and download the APK‚Äôs yourselves.

Thank you, and thanks to all the people who have been trying this out for the last couple weeks! Happy testing!

link_counts.title: Obtainium Apps

posts.cooked:
I have question about the Signal version in the Obtainium App repository. the app config is pointing to

https://updates.signal.org/android/latest.json

that in turn points to a specific .apk possibly hosted on Signal server

https://updates.signal.org/android/Signal-Android-website-prod-universal-release-7.28.4.apk

is this the same as installing the app manually using the GitHub repo (as detailed in the first post)?
in the case of GH the .apk is hosted on GH servers.
is there any difference security wise between the two methods?

finally, is there a preferred/recommended method? or are they equivalent? thanks

There is no difference between the two installation methods. It is the same apk that is being installed on your system. There is no difference security-wise with the non-worrisome exception that if you already are using Obtainium to manage other apps, then you don‚Äôt need to authorize Signal to be able to install apk files.

I don‚Äôt know how the Signal app itself looks for a new available apk. It used to only look to the apk published on Signal.org. Those apk files were not published until a full rollout on Google Play. I get the impression that apk files are published on Github more quickly than on the website. If this is true, then Obtainium would notify you of a new version before the native Signal app would.

link_counts.title: Signal >> Home

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
CueHD:

I get the impression that apk files are published on Github more quickly than on the website.

This is correct. The website version is always the stable build which only gets updated once per week.

posts.name: Josh Lemon
posts.cooked:
This is brilliant!
It was as easy to setup as described.

Question - is there any possibility to roll back if we ever get a bad Beta update with this method? I know it‚Äôs fairly rare now, but every now and then we have a beta that really breaks things.

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
JoshLemon:

is there any possibility to roll back if we ever get a bad Beta update with this method?

Unfortunately Android itself doesn‚Äôt really let you roll back. It will refuse to install versions with lower versionCode‚Äôs than the one you have installed. Apologies!

greyson-signal:

It will refuse to install versions with lower versionCode‚Äôs than the one you have installed.

The proper way is. Developer in source code reverts faulty commit, does the proper testing, releases new version and Android gets new versionCode.

Android preventing installing older version is intentional, because it can break the data application possesses. For example when new version of application is installed during version upgrade application adds new columns to table, changes data types etc. Installing back the older version it would be required to undo the changes: drop columns from table, change back data types etc, but in this case you can lose the data in that dropped column and in shrank attributes etc. In many cases reverse order is not desirable or in some cases not even possible like older version of application requires some data that new version does not anymore and so during upgrade those data are deleted and so downgrade is not possible.

Probably suppose downgrade would be possible, if user agrees to delete all of application data. This may be no problem in application like Calculator, but not for Signal where data in application is pretty important - for example you have added user with username and this username is then deleted by your friend. You can‚Äôt pair this user anymore.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
pointing it out as this keeps coming up: GitHub releases are aimed at beta testers, and so if you point your Obtainium at the GitHub repo, you‚Äôre getting a beta release, with all that it means.
if you want a stable release, don‚Äôt want to get it from Google Play and don‚Äôt want to download manually, the Signal.org website apk is auto-updating, meaning you don‚Äôt need Google Play: Signal >> Signal Android APK
it is also possible to point your Obtainium at the website APK as described here:

Availability of Android releases (Google Play, Firebase, APK, etc.) Android Discussion
Use the following links to add either the website version of the production version or the beta version to Obtainium.

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked: Hey folks, just updated the instructions to note that if you want the latest beta, you now have to toggle ‚Äúenable prereleases‚Äù. This is in response to some feedback on github that we should properly label non-prod releases as pre-releases, which is a fair point. So we do that now

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
greyson-signal:

if you want the latest beta, you now have to toggle ‚Äúenable prereleases‚Äù.

  1. Open Obtanium
  2. Tap Signal
  3. Tap the pencil
  4. Toggle ‚Äúinclude pre-releases‚Äù to on

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Thank you, this is a good move :)

JoshLemon:

is there any possibility to roll back if we ever get a bad Beta update with this method?

Technically, if you really needed to, you could probably fork an older version of the repo, change the version number to something higher than the current version and then install that. You should of course check that no changes were made that will be an issue when downgrading and choose a version number that is in between official numbers, so there won‚Äôt be a conflict when upgrading to a new official release.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
rollback is not really intended, in general, with APKs. even in the Firebase days, a rollback essentially amounted to un- and re-installing. so if you‚Äôre on Signal beta, be it Google Play or GitHub, you need to do one of the following things:

  1. have a connected device that‚Äôs not on beta such that if you ever encounter a bad release you‚Äôre not locked out of your account
  2. have regular backups such that you can delete the app and restore to an old version
  3. be okay with having to wait for a new release to be able to access your account again.
